comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: Smashing uniform, and well polished kit, he kept his batman busy!

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: very good looking and  a great smile!

comment.author: 74582320@N00
comment._content: He is not wearing any insignia on his shoulders. He is, however, wearing a sidearm. This is typical for officers of that time. May I suggest an Irish historical society? As for the compt... he very well could have been a military comptroller, as well as a civilian accountant assigned to the military for the purposes of helping the units with their finances and accountancy. That may account (no pun) for the lack of insignia. His rank could have been, therefore, honorary.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/estabrook] Aaah! That might explain the Compt. alright )though not why he was Capt. in the other photo taken of him that day)... Thank you, Mark!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 26033330@N00
comment._content:
It would seem that "comptroller" is meant here, but in the sense it was used in the British military, which was usually as a temporary military governor and was not an actual rank so much as a description of an assumed role, which is probably why you're having difficulty researching it. You'll find this term mainly used in wartime situations of the British Empire in India and further east. Captain would have been his actual rank. This is almost certainly a fighting man as finance was pretty much run from Dublin at the time. They didn't want any of that falling into the hands of the anti-Treaty forces. 

One of my history teachers, years ago, said that the gold from the Central Bank (or its then equivalent) almost fell into the hands of an anti-Treaty flying column that reached the city, but that Vinny Byrne, one of Michael Collins' full-time assassins in the Squad, single-handedly held them off with two pistols, with the threat that he wouldn't get them all but he'd get enough of them. His reputation was so notorious that they backed off, and this event was apparently in reality the most decisive and important event in the entire Civil War in terms of all that occurred afterwards. So I was told...

comment.author: 26033330@N00
comment._content: PS - the badge on his hat should indicate rank. Stripes would have been right out due to the sheer amount of sniper activity throughout this war, although it didn't help Michael Collins much.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sam2cents] Thanks for all this. Comptroller it would seem to be then... p.s. your photos are pretty amazing e.g. www.flickr.com/photos/sam2cents/3926265520/
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Photo may have been taken at the union (Poor Law Union) workhouse on John's Hill Waterford. Now partially demolish  dand known as St Patrick's Hospital.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Thanks for this suggestion! I've added it under the photo above to see if others agree with you... Hope you don't mind, and I'm sure you may be right, but would like confimation before adding it definitely.

comment.author: 92847932@N06
comment._content: I've just found the other photo of him taken on that day online and was surprised to find that  have a copy of that photo that I was given by family and was told that my great grandad Comndt James Hetherington  was pictured. The quality of the photo that I have is very poor and always thought that my Great grandad was the man in the tie, however, after seeing the pictures online I'm now not sure. Could there be a mistake in the first name?? And this actually be James Hetherington. I am waiting for family to see the pictures too to clarify for me. There was also a picture of my great grandad in his uniform which hung in the family home in Waterford but has since been lost ? If this is it.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92847932@N06] Hello. Is this the other photo that you mean - the group one? Although it does say Paul, there certainly could be an error in the name... You should check this great online resource - the Military Archives Irish Army Census Records...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 92847932@N06
comment._content: Hi, yes that's the photo, the group one, the copy I have is really tatty so it's great to see the original. I've just spoken to my dad, he thinks the photo is my great grandad James but will ask ( senior) members of family to confirm. I've had a look at the military census, can't find him on there. I have got lots of info/pictures on him via the Munster express online so will have a search through that.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/92847932@N06] Thanks very much. Please do come back to us if you get confirmation that this was James rather than Paul.

You know it also struck me that Paul wasn't a very popular name back at the end of the 19th/beginning of the 20th century. So I searched the 1911 census, and the score is:
James  229,854  :  Paul  1,970
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 92847932@N06
comment._content: Had it confirmed by senior family members that this man isn't our relation, however, in the group photo the man in the tie sat next to "Paul Hetherington" is definately my great great grandfather James Hetherington who was a Comndt in the National Army in Waterford. ?? If Paul Hetherington was a relation but my family members do not recognise him, nor have I found any relation of that name/ time whilst researching the family tree.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Tak e look at this Streetview of one of the surviving Union Workhouse buildings. It has stone surrounds around the windows, and a porch leading to an arch into the building proper. I don't think it is the same spot exactly: the windows in the streetview seem smaller and the porch is a different design, but the architecture is similar enough that I think it's plausible that the original is another building at the Union Workhouse.
